proposals.reasoning: This follows my earlier preference to avoid defaulting into the same Bob+Charlie opener we’ve used before, while still including a widely trusted early-game player (Bob). Starting with Bob+Diana gives us a straightforward, low-drama team that also mixes patterns enough to generate cleaner information for later missions without overcommitting to any strong reads in Quest 1.

votes.comment: Bob is a solid opener and Quest 1 isn’t high stakes; I’d prefer Bob+Charlie but this is still a fine low-info first team.
I’m on the team and early Q1 data is low-stakes; this setup keeps options open without looking suspicious.
Having my evil teammate on a small first mission is good for us, and Quest 1 is usually low-info so I’m fine with this lineup.
Consistent with my earlier preference to avoid the usual Bob+Charlie opener; this lineup is reasonable for low-info Quest 1.
Slight preference for Bob+Charlie, but Bob+Diana is still a reasonable low-info opener and I don’t want to waste an early proposal cycle.
I preferred Bob+Charlie as the cleaner, more consensus, and more readable opener; I don’t want to deviate from that without a strong reason.

discussion.content: For the first team I’d rather start with people who tend to play straightforward and low-drama, so I’m leaning toward someone like Bob plus either Charlie or Diana. We shouldn’t lock in strong reads yet, but that combo feels like a reasonable low-risk opener.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I’d slightly prefer pairing with Charlie over Diana just based on past games where Charlie’s been pretty steady on early missions. That said, I don’t think we should over-read Quest 1 either way.

I’m okay with Bob + me as an opener since we’ve both played pretty straightforward early on in past games, but I don’t want us to overcommit to any hard reads from Quest 1 results. If people are uneasy about that, I’d also be fine with Bob + Diana as an alternative.

I’m good with Bob on the first team, but I’d slightly lean Bob + Diana over Bob + Charlie just so we don’t default too hard into the same early-game pairing patterns. It gives us a cleaner data point if something weird happens later.

I slightly prefer starting with Bob + Charlie since their early-game styles have been pretty transparent in past games, and a clean result there gives us a clearer baseline. I’d still accept Bob + Diana if table consensus leans that way, but I’d like at least one of them on every early mission.

I slightly prefer Bob + Charlie for the first team since both have been pretty readable early in past games, and a clean result there gives us a solid baseline. If people really want to mix it up, Bob + Diana is okay, but I’d rather start with the more transparent pair.

proposals.reasoning: We keep Bob as the common anchor from the clean first mission, add Alice as a strong early info read, and include myself so we test a new two-person combination with Bob without auto-locking Diana again off a single 2-player success. If this team fails, suspicion cleanly narrows to Alice/Eve versus Bob; if it succeeds, we’ve likely identified a solid good core while still leaving room to compare against teams including Diana, Charlie, or Frank later.

votes.comment: Bob is slightly townleaned from the clean first mission, I know I’m good, and adding Eve gives us new info without re-locking Diana; reasonable early-game team to test.
I’m on the team after a clean Mission 1 and this lineup fits the general table preferences for testing new combos without auto‑locking Diana.
Bob as anchor from a clean M1 plus two new players gives good info either way, and I don’t see a strong reason to block this setup yet.
Keeps Bob from a clean M1 while adding two new players for better info; no obvious reason to distrust this mix yet.
Includes me and the clean M1 anchor Bob while testing Alice; good early info and doesn’t auto-lock Diana based on a 2-player success.
Good informational team keeping Bob from the clean M1 while testing two new players; nothing strong enough yet to justify rejecting this early.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’m pretty comfortable keeping Bob on the team, and I’d like at least one of Charlie or Diana on this one so we’re not completely flying blind on info reads yet.
I’m happy to stay on after a clean Mission 1, and I’d lean toward adding Charlie here so we get some new info rather than just repeating the exact same core.

I like keeping Bob after a clean first mission, and I’m fine hopping on here so we get some fresh info with a new third. Between Diana and Eve for the last slot, I’d slightly lean Diana just so we’re not double-dipping on total unknowns yet.

Given the clean Bob + me start, I’d rather stick with that pair and add a fresh third like Alice or Eve than lock in Charlie this early off basically no info. That way if something goes wrong, we’ve got a clearer comparison than “we just trusted the consensus pick.”

I’m good keeping Bob as a core after a clean M1, but I’d rather add one of Alice or Charlie than auto-lock Diana again off a 2‑person success. If we do see a fail, having that mix gives us clearer comparisons than just rerunning the same pair.
I’d keep Bob as the common anchor from the clean first mission and add one of Alice or Charlie, but I’d rather not auto‑lock Diana back in yet so we don’t just tunnel on that initial pair.

proposals.reasoning: We’re 2–0 with Bob on both successful missions and Alice/Eve on the clean second mission, so the safest high-odds core is to keep that proven trio together. To avoid going into later missions with me completely untested, I add only one new player—myself—as the fourth slot, rather than introducing two fresh players at once. This maximizes continuity with what has already worked while giving the table new alignment information with minimal added risk of accidentally pairing two unknown evils.

votes.comment: I like keeping the proven Bob–Alice–Eve core, but adding the completely untested Frank over reusing Diana from a clean Mission 1 feels like unnecessary extra risk for our first 4-person team.
I’m on the team and we need a fail soon; this is a widely supported, high-trust lineup that’s good for slipping in a sabotage.
My evil teammate Bob is on the team, giving us sabotage potential without exposing both evils at once, so I want this to go through.
Keeps the fully clean Bob–Alice–Eve core and adds only one new member, which is the most reasonable low-variance choice at 2–0.
Core of Bob+Alice+me just succeeded on Mission 2; adding only one new player (Frank) is a reasonable low-variance test at 2–0, even though I’d have slightly preferred Charlie as the new slot.
I’m on it and know I’m good; keeping the fully clean Bob–Alice–Eve trio together plus adding a single new player is a reasonable, low-variance way to test me while preserving what’s already worked.

discussion.content:
Given two clean missions with Bob on both, I’m pretty comfortable keeping Bob on the team, and I’d like to add at least one of Charlie or Diana plus one of Eve/Frank so we’re not just repeating the exact same trio again.  
I’m slightly more wary of Frank only because he hasn’t been on a mission yet, but I don’t want a completely untested lineup either.

I agree I should probably stay on, and I’m inclined to keep at least one of Diana/Eve from the earlier successes while adding Charlie as a fresh test rather than pulling in Frank and having two completely untested spots at once.

I’m on board with keeping Bob given two clean hits, and I’d like to see a mix of known and new, so something like Bob + one of Diana/Eve + me as a fresh test feels reasonable, with the fourth spot between Alice/Eve depending on how safe we want to play it.

Given we’re 2–0, I’d rather lean safer and mostly reuse what’s worked: I like Bob plus some combo of Alice/Eve/me, with just one new person added. Between Charlie and Frank as the “fresh test,” I slightly prefer trying Frank first since Charlie’s mostly been echoing consensus so far.

I definitely want to keep Bob after two clean missions, and I’d like to keep it mostly “proven” by adding one of Alice/Diana plus only one new face—between Charlie and Frank, I slightly prefer testing Charlie first since we’ve at least seen more of his table talk.

I think Bob is mandatory, and I’d like a mostly “proven” core of Bob plus two of Alice/Diana/Eve, with just one new test—personally I’d lean to trying me now alongside that rather than leaving me completely untested going into the later missions.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2 with exactly this trio passed cleanly, and Mission 3 only failed when Frank was added to that proven group, producing exactly one fail card. The simplest and most consistent explanation is that Frank is the lone saboteur from that mission and Bob/Alice/Eve are all good. With the score at 2–1, evil must fail this mission to stay in the game, so we should prioritize the configuration that already demonstrated a clean result and exclude the only new variable from the failed mission (Frank). Keeping Charlie and Diana off avoids introducing any untested risk when we already have a strong candidate for an all-good team.

votes.comment: Most consistent explanation of the results is that Frank was the new saboteur on Mission 3; rerunning the previously clean Bob–Alice–Eve trio is our highest-percentage shot at an all-good team without introducing new risk.
I’m on it and Frank is off, so this keeps the main suspicion away from me while still giving evil a chance to fail the mission.
Includes Bob as the only likely evil, giving us a chance to fail the mission while keeping strong table consensus on this ‘proven’ trio.
Matches the previously clean trio and excludes the only new variable from the failed mission, minimizing risk.
Same trio was clean on Mission 2; Mission 3 only failed when Frank was added, so this is our highest-confidence all-good team.

From my perspective as a good player, the only way Mission 3 fails with 1 card after 2 clean missions is if at least one of Bob/Alice/Eve is evil and chose to fail when I joined; rerunning that exact trio is not a guaranteed safe team for me.

discussion.content: Given that the only change between the clean mission and the failed one was adding Frank, I’d strongly prefer a team of Bob, Alice, and Eve again, or at minimum keep Frank off this mission.

I agree we should keep Frank off, but I don’t think we can just lock in “Bob–Alice–Eve” as pure based on one fail; I’d like to see a team with me plus two of Alice/Eve/Diana to at least test a slightly different mix.

Given Bob’s been on both clean missions and the fail only showed up when Frank joined, I’d rather keep Bob and rotate the third slot among Alice/Eve/Diana than lock into the exact same trio. Maybe something like Bob–Alice–Diana or Bob–Eve–Diana to both keep a “proven” core and re-test Diana.

I’m on board with keeping Frank off this one, and from what we’ve seen so far I’m most comfortable with teams drawn from Bob, Alice, Eve, and myself. Maybe we either just rerun Bob–Alice–Eve, or try Bob–Alice–Diana if people want a slightly different but still “mostly proven” mix.

I’m very wary of Frank after that last swap, so for this mission I’d strongly prefer we stick to some combo of Bob, Alice, and me, or if we really want a change, Bob–Alice–Diana while still keeping Frank off.

Given the info we have, I’m fine staying off this one, and I think the safest pick right now is to stick with the proven trio of Bob–Alice–Eve. If people really want a tweak, Bob–Alice–Diana also makes sense, but I wouldn’t break away from that Bob/Alice core.

proposals.reasoning: We need to break the poisoned Alice/Bob/Eve core that produced the last two single-fail missions, but also not throw out all of our earlier information. I’m keeping myself because I was on both early clean missions, and most people have said that, if you keep one from the Alice/Bob/Eve trio, it should be me. Charlie is the most broadly acceptable fresh anchor that isn’t tied to those fails, and several of you (including Alice and Frank) have already suggested building around Charlie plus the more trusted players. Between Diana and Frank, they’ve stayed relatively consistent and weren’t part of the failing 3- and 4-person cores together, and multiple proposals have mentioned them as preferred adds. This team of Bob/Charlie/Diana/Frank is the closest compromise across the table: it benches the contentious Alice–Eve pairing completely, preserves the early-read trust on me, uses Charlie as the new anchor, and includes the two most commonly suggested supporting picks for the decider.

votes.comment: As Percival I know exactly one of Charlie/Diana is evil (Morgana), so this team guarantees at least one spy, and if Bob is also the spy from the repeated failing core it could even contain two.
Both evils are on this team, so we can guarantee a fail and win the game.
This matches the fresh-core plan I argued for: keep Bob from the early cleans, add me plus Diana and Frank, and fully bench the Alice/Eve pair that anchored both failed teams.
I’m still uncomfortable hinging the last mission on a completely untested Charlie while benching both Alice and Eve; this doesn’t match the team structure I’ve been pushing for.

At least one of Alice/Bob is evil from the last two fails; there’s no reason to accept a decider team that keeps Bob when we can build a team benching both Alice and Bob and cap the risk at at most one unknown evil.
I still don’t want Bob on the decider when both fails came from the Alice/Bob/Eve core and we haven’t yet tested a Bob-less team; I’d rather run Charlie, Diana, me plus one of Alice/Eve.

proposals.reasoning: Both fails came from the repeated Alice/Bob/Eve core, but Bob was also on the two early clean missions, while Alice and Eve were only ever seen in combination with that later poisoned core. If we assume at least one of Alice/Eve is bad, the most consistent adjustment is to bench that whole pair and form a fresh team around the players least implicated by the fail pattern. Bob has the strongest claim to being good from Missions 1 and 2, and Diana and Frank have only been on a single failed mission each, always alongside the already-suspect Alice/Eve cluster. I’m including myself as the only completely untested player to break away from the previous configurations and avoid re‑running the same problematic core. This lineup maximizes use of early clean info while minimizing reliance on the Alice/Eve pair that’s been present on both fails.

votes.comment: This team is only fully clean if both Alice and Eve are the exact evil pair, which is a narrow read. With Bob on every mission—including both fails—and Diana/Frank each touched a fail once, I’d rather not stake the game on BCDF when it can easily contain 1–2 evils.
Both evils are on this team, so we guarantee a chance to sabotage the final mission.
This best incorporates the early clean info around Bob while avoiding the repeatedly failing Alice/Eve core, and it finally tests a fresh configuration for the decider.

I still don’t like hinging the last mission on a completely untested Charlie while also keeping Bob, who’s been on every single team including both fails. I’d rather have at most one of {Bob, Charlie} on the decider, not both.

As a known-to-myself good player, the only guaranteed winning team for good must include me; any 4-player team from the other 5 necessarily contains at least one of the two evils, so this lineup can’t be fully clean on the final mission.
Most consistent clean world is both Alice and Eve being evil from the repeated failing core, which makes Bob/Charlie/Diana/Frank an all-good team that benches the poisoned Alice/Eve pair.

proposals.reasoning: Both failed missions shared the exact Alice/Bob/Eve core with Bob present on every single team so far, making him the strongest structural suspect as the common denominator. By benching Bob and also keeping completely untested Charlie off the decider, we avoid hinging the game on either the most involved player or a zero‑data wild card. This lineup keeps two players (Alice, Eve) who were part of an earlier clean mission, adds me as a known-clean from Mission 1, and includes Frank—whose only appearance was on the single‑fail Mission 3, but that fail can be consistently explained by Bob if he is the shared bad actor. This team balances prior mission information with risk reduction by removing the highest-leverage suspect and the least-tested player.

votes.comment: This team only works if both Bob and Charlie are evil, but given one of Charlie/Diana is Merlin, their pro-Bob stances make Bob more likely good. That makes it very likely at least one of Alice/Diana/Eve/Frank here is evil, so I don’t want to bench both Bob and Charlie on the decider.
This benches both me and Charlie and locks in a zero-evil team, which doesn’t match my stated preference for including myself as part of the core after two fails on the same trio.

Both fails came from the Alice/Bob/Eve core, but I still trust Bob more than the Alice/Eve pair given the two early cleans. Benching Bob while keeping both Alice and Eve on the final mission doesn’t fit my reads, so I can’t support this lineup.
This keeps both Alice and Eve from the back-to-back failing core on the same team, which I argued earlier was too risky; I’d rather only take one of that pair on the final mission.

I know I’m good, so the two single-fail missions mean at least one of Alice/Bob is evil. This team still includes Alice instead of benching the entire poisoned Alice/Bob/Eve core, when we can still try a cleaner bench-both-Alice-and-Bob lineup on the next proposal.

This team is only fully good if the exact evil pair is {Bob, Charlie}. In every other consistent world at least one of Alice/Diana/Eve is evil, so this lineup carries very high fail risk for the decider.

proposals.reasoning: Both failed missions 3 and 4 shared the exact Alice/Bob/Eve core; since I know I’m good, the fails must have come from at least one of Alice or Bob, plus exactly one of Charlie/Diana/Frank. Mission 4’s fail came from either Alice or Bob (only they could have played FAIL), and mission 3’s extra member was Frank, making him a prime suspect as the second evil. The behavioral pattern of both Alice and Frank pushing suspicion toward Bob is also consistent with them being partnered and framing him. Under that read, the good set is {Bob, Charlie, Diana, Eve}, so the best chance for a clean success is to take Bob, Charlie, Diana, and myself while benching Alice and Frank.

votes.comment: I know I’m good, so at least one of Bob/Eve must be evil from the repeated single-fail core; this team includes both of them and benches me, so it guarantees at least one evil on the mission.
This matches the good block I’ve been arguing for (me + Charlie as core plus Diana/Eve), and it avoids the repeatedly failing Alice/Eve core while benching my main alternative suspect, Frank.
Both evils are on this team, giving us the chance to play a FAIL and win.
This swings too hard from your earlier idea of benching the Alice/Bob pair and now adds completely untested Charlie for the decider; I don’t want to risk the last mission on that mix.

Benching both Alice and Frank fits the most coherent evil-pair read (Alice+Frank framing Bob). Any team must include exactly one of Alice/Bob; given Alice’s leading the repeat-fail core and Frank’s presence on Mission 3’s fail plus his push to bench Bob, I’m more inclined to trust Bob here and run Bob/Charlie/Diana/Eve.
Given I know I’m good, every consistent assignment of 2 evils puts at least one evil on this team (Bob, Charlie, Diana, or Eve), so it cannot be fully clean from my perspective.

proposals.reasoning: Both mission fails came from the exact Alice/Bob/Eve core, and I know as Frank that I did not play FAIL on Mission 3, so the Mission 3 fail had to come from at least one of Alice/Bob/Eve. Mission 4 then failed again with the same trio (without me), reinforcing that at least one of that group is evil. Bob is the only player who has been on every single team, including both fails, which makes him the most dangerous to keep on the decider. Among the non-core players, I know I’m good; that means the two evils must be either (1) one or two in {Alice, Bob, Eve} plus possibly one of {Charlie, Diana}, or (2) both in {Alice, Bob, Eve}. Crucially, at most one of Charlie/Diana can be evil, because we already know there is at least one evil in the Alice/Bob/Eve trio from the fail on Mission 3 when I was present. Therefore, a team built around Charlie and Diana with me included minimizes the chance of hitting two evils outside that trio. To break the poisoned core, we remove Bob entirely and bring in only one of Alice/Eve. I slightly prefer Eve over Alice based on discussion dynamics and my earlier stated preference, so the final team is Charlie, Diana, Eve, and myself, deliberately benching Bob and Alice to avoid the repeatedly failing core.

discussion.content: We can’t run the exact Alice/Bob/Eve core again after back‑to‑back single fails, so at least one of them has to sit. I’d rather anchor the last team around Charlie plus either Diana or Frank, and only take at most one of Bob/Eve.

If we think the repeat Alice/Bob/Eve core is poisoned, the most consistent read is that at least one of Alice/Eve is bad, not me, since I was on both early cleans too. I’d like a team built around Charlie + me as the new core, then choose two of Diana/Frank/Alice based on who people feel least worried about.

Given the two clean early missions, I’m inclined to trust Bob more than the Alice/Eve pair, so I’d like to see a fresh team of Bob, me, Diana, and Frank and just bench the whole Alice/Eve core for the decider.

I’m not super happy about benching both Alice and Eve and then hinging the game on bringing in completely untested Charlie, so I’d rather see something like Bob, me, Frank, plus one of Alice/Eve (leaning Eve slightly) for the last team.

Given I know I’m good, the only consistent way to get single fails on both 3 and 4 is that at least one of Alice/Bob is dirty, so I’d really like a team that benches that whole pair and runs something like me, Charlie, Diana, and Frank.

Given both fails came on the exact Alice/Bob/Eve core and Bob’s been on every single team, I’m most uncomfortable keeping him on the decider. I’d like to see a team of Charlie, Diana, me, plus one of Alice/Eve (slight lean to including Eve) and leave Bob out.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well maintaining a generally trustworthy image and supporting early successful teams, but I failed to correctly distinguish Merlin from Morgana and didn't press hard enough on the implications of the late mission fails. I need to be more vocal about my Merlin read earlier and reevaluate my assumptions after each mission result instead of clinging to an initial narrative.

player_observations.Bob: Played very solid, central 'good leader' vibes by being on early successful missions and using that to anchor trust later, which effectively masked his Mordred role.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively out of the spotlight early and let others define the narrative, which is a classic Morgana approach that made their potential Merlin signals harder to confidently read.
player_observations.Diana: Gave subtle but consistent nudges toward good team compositions without over-asserting, which is strong Merlin play but also made it easier for evil to keep her from becoming an obvious target.
player_observations.Eve: Came across straightforward and earnest, generally accepting popular team proposals and projecting a very natural good-player mindset, though occasionally a bit too trusting of established narratives.
player_observations.Frank: Adopted a cautious, somewhat reactive style—more following the table’s logic than driving it—which made him look generically good but not especially cleared until the late missions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I timed my visible support for early missions well, which built enough trust to get onto critical teams while staying under the radar as evil. I could improve by more actively shaping narratives about who was suspicious, especially earlier, so that late-game team choices felt more constrained toward including at least one evil player.

player_observations.Alice: Very assertive in team discussions and seemed comfortable taking leadership, which helped her get on many teams but also made her a focal point for suspicion after the first fail. As Percival, she appeared to balance trusting her Merlin read with her own logic, though that sometimes made her hesitant to hard-clear anyone.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a relatively low-profile Morgana, which helped avoid direct heat while still subtly nudging suspicion elsewhere. Their presence on the final failing team suggests they were good at appearing just trustworthy enough to be included without heavy scrutiny.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious about pushing too hard, which kept her from being obviously targeted but also limited how forcefully she could steer teams away from evil. Her influence was noticeable but not domineering, creating a vibe of quiet reason rather than overt control.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as very straightforward and genuinely good-leaning, which made her an attractive and consistent team pick. However, that same predictability sometimes made her easier to manipulate into accepting slightly risky teams that still felt safe to her.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a strong inclination toward logical justification of team choices, often wanting a clear narrative before committing. This analytical style made him valuable in discussions, but also left him vulnerable when evil could feed him just enough plausible logic to get him to back a losing team.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed mostly believable as a potential Merlin/percival candidate and helped keep suspicion spread out, especially by allowing early missions to pass and not overdirecting discussions. I could improve by more actively shaping the narrative earlier (especially around Mission 2–3) to frame specific goods as suspicious instead of mostly reacting, which would have given evil more control over team compositions.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very analytical Percival, constantly cross-checking voting patterns and mission results, but seemed slightly overconfident in her Merlin read, which made her pushes somewhat predictable and exploitable.
player_observations.Bob: As Mordred, he blended in well with the good team, especially by taking part in early successes, and kept his tone low-key and non-leading, which made him a very safe inclusion on teams.
player_observations.Diana: As Merlin, she was cautious and subtle, rarely hard-pushing any one narrative, which protected her identity but sometimes made her reads less influential in team debates.
player_observations.Eve: Tended to follow the louder voices and table consensus, which made her look fairly neutral/innocent but also made her easier to steer when constructing or criticizing teams.
player_observations.Frank: Played with a straightforward, almost mechanical logic focus—trying to deduce from mission outcomes more than social cues—which made him resistant to pure rhetoric but also a bit slow to adjust to evolving narratives.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I correctly trusted Bob early and pushed successful teams at the start, which helped establish some goodwill and made my Merlin reads less obvious. However, I failed to clearly steer missions 3–5 away from the double-evil core of Bob/Charlie without outing myself, and I didn’t do enough to keep suspicion and mission leadership pressure focused on Bob after the first fail.

player_observations.Alice: Played very proactively and embraced mission leadership, which fit well with being a visible good role; her willingness to go on risky teams made her look bold but occasionally gave evil good cover.
player_observations.Bob: Maintained a very steady, trustworthy presence as Mordred, leveraging the early successes to anchor himself as ‘confirmed-ish’ and then slipping a single fail into mid/late missions in a controlled way.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar while quietly aligning with evil outcomes, letting others drive team discussions; felt like a classic support-evil style that avoids drawing direct suspicion.
player_observations.Eve: Played cautiously good, generally accepting consensus teams and not forcing strong counter-narratives, which made her look sincere but also made it easier for evil to co-opt her trust.
player_observations.Frank: Showed a mix of skepticism and flexibility, but as a good player he sometimes gave too much benefit of the doubt to early successful lineups, which let evil sneak onto his later mission without heavy challenge.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I did well maintaining a consistently trustworthy presence, which helped get early good teams approved and kept suspicion relatively low on me throughout the game. However, I could have pushed harder to re-evaluate my reads after the first fail on Mission 3 and been more vocal about resisting later teams that mixed too many previously exposed or risky players, especially around Frank’s final team.

player_observations.Alice: Played a solid, proactive info role; her willingness to go on multiple critical teams and take leadership made her look confident and good-aligned, though she may have overtrusted Bob for too long.
player_observations.Bob: Very steady and composed; he leveraged early mission success to cement massive trust and avoided drawing attention even after being on multiple pivotal teams, a classic, low-flash but highly effective evil style.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed mostly in the background and avoided major team spots until the final mission, which kept suspicion low and allowed evil to preserve a hidden resource for the endgame.
player_observations.Diana: Projected calm, logical leadership and constructed believable narratives that fit the mission results, which is exactly what made her Merlin reads blend nicely into normal good play.
player_observations.Frank: Came across as earnest and generally trustworthy but a bit indecisive; as leader on Missions 3 and 5, he seemed to lean too much on established trust (especially in Bob) rather than aggressively challenging earlier assumptions.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I was too slow to lock in on Bob as the consistent source of mission fails and let that uncertainty push me into a risky final-team choice that included Charlie instead of a more statistically safe configuration. I did reasonably well trusting Diana and Eve by the end, but I should have pushed harder against keeping Bob on missions after Mission 3 and recognized the pattern of single-fail missions pointing to him.

player_observations.Alice: Played a very central information role and built trust early with clean missions, but her association with Bob on the failing Mission 4 made reading her alignment tricky from my perspective.
player_observations.Bob: Blended in extremely well as evil by anchoring early successful missions and then consistently sabotaging from inside trusted teams, leveraging that trust so we kept including him despite the pattern of single fails.
player_observations.Charlie: Stayed relatively under the radar for most of the game and benefited from not being heavily tested on early missions, which made it easier for you to slip onto the final team as hidden evil.
player_observations.Diana: Your play as Merlin was subtle but not forceful; you seemed to avoid hard accusations, which kept you safe but also made it harder for me to confidently follow your reads.
player_observations.Eve: Came across as steadily good and trustworthy through repeated successful missions and calm team selections, though your presence on failing teams with Bob made it hard to completely clear you until late.
